Award.AwardTitle: Interaction of Low-energy Positrons with Atoms and Molecules
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project focuses on experimental studies of the interaction of low-energy positrons with atoms and molecules using a high-resolution, trap-based positron beam and specially designed techniques to study scattering and annihilation processes. Recent theoretical and experimental results provide new topics for study, including understanding the nature of the orders-of-magnitude enhancements of positron annihilation on molecules that is mediated by vibrational Feshbach resonances. Key objectives of the research include understanding the nature of these resonances and the associated phenomena of positron binding to molecules and intramolecular vibrational energy redistribution. Other research topics include studies of resonance and threshold effects in positron scattering and studies of new targets including carbon-60 and metal atoms. In the broader view, the work seeks to establish aspects of a quantitative chemistry of matter and antimatter.

The work can be expected to aid in enabling technological applications of low energy positrons, such as developing new methods to ionize large molecules and a new generation of positron beam sources for the characterization of materials. While focusing on research in atomic physics involving antimatter, this project also has impacts in other areas. It involves graduate student and post-doctoral researchers at all levels from the planning of experiments to the dissemination of research results. The project involves small-scale experiments that are an excellent training ground for scientific and technical personnel. The work is communicated broadly, not only to physics audiences but also to those involved in plasma, chemical, and materials science, and gaseous electronics research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit. This project involved experimental studies of the interaction of low-energy positrons (i.e., the antiparticles of electrons) with molecules. The investigators discovered that positrons can attach to molecules. This process produces bound complexes that can live for nanoseconds, in turn producing enhanced rates of annihilation of the positron with the molecular electrons. The nature of the attachment and annihilation processes provides a convenient way to measure positron-molecule binding energies. These data represent the first experimental measurements of positron binding to either atoms or molecules. The results are relevant to many applications of low energy positrons.

Important results included positron binding energy measurements for more than thirty new molecules and systematic studies of several chemical species. They include aldehyde, nitrile and ketone molecules, all of which have large permanent dipole moments. The results of these studies led to a greater understanding of the molecular properties that determine positron binding. These results provided the first comparisons of experimentally measured and theoretically predicted binding energies for either atoms or molecules. The results also enabled the first comparisons of the properties of positron-molecule bound states with analogous electron-molecule (negative-ion) states. Positrons were found to bind to analogous molecules a factor of 10 to 100 times more strongly than electrons. Comparison to contemporary calculations provides a model of this effect in terms of the differences in the nature of the localization of the positron and electron on the molecule.

Broader Impacts. While this project focused on aspects of the low-energy interaction of antimatter (positrons) with ordinary matter, in the broader view, it established important aspects of a quantitative physical and chemical description of the interaction of antimatter with matter.
